questions.text: A 36-year-old pregnant woman with a history of gestational diabetes in her previous pregnancy presents for her routine prenatal visit at 32 weeks of gestation. She is concerned about her current baby's growth. Which of the following is most appropriate to assess fetal growth?
questions.explanation:
• Clinical:
    • Maternal weight
    • Maternal BP
    • Size of uterus
    • Height of fundus
  • Biochemical: Amniocentesis for assessing fetal pulmonary maturity
  • Biophysical:
    • Fetal movement count
    • Ultrasonography
    • Cardiotocography
    • Nonstress test (NST) (Option A ruled out)
    • Fetal biophysical profile (BPP)
    • Doppler ultrasound (Option C ruled out)
    • Vibroacoustic stimulation test
    • Contraction stress test (CST)
    • Amniotic fluid volume (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding nutritional status in pregnancy is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The increased calorie requirement is 400 kcal over the non pregnancy state during the second half of pregnancy.

options.label: B
options.text: The optimum weight gain during pregnancy is 10-12 kg for a normal BMI woman.

options.label: C
options.text: The daily dietary allowance of iron in lactating women is 200mcg.

options.label: D
options.text: Excessive weight gain decreases the intrapartum complications .

questions.correct_answer: B. The optimum weight gain during pregnancy is 10-12 kg for a normal BMI woman.
questions.explanation:
Calories

During pregnancy
  • +350 kcal  (Option A ruled out)

During lactation
  • +600Kcal in first 6 months of lactation(1-6M)
  • +520Kcal in the next 6 months of lactation (7-12M)

questions.text: A 26-year-old newly married woman came to the OPD with a positive urine pregnancy test. She has a history of antiepileptic drug usage for the past 5 years. Which of the following would you advise the patient? Anti-epileptic drug has to be continued Immediately stop the anti-epileptic once pregnancy is detected Folate supplementation of 4 mcg/day is given No anti-epileptic drug is deemed safe in pregnancy
questions.explanation:
Antiepileptic drug

Associated malformation

Valproate

 
  • Neural tube defects
  • Cardiac defects
  • Cleft lip
  • Cleft palate
  • Developmental delay
  • ADHD

Phenytoin
  • Fetal Hydantoin syndrome
    • Cranio- facial anomalies
    • Fingernail hypoplasia
    • Developmental delay
    • Cardiac anomalies

Phenobarbital
  • Cleft lip and palate
  • Cardiac anomalies
  • UT malformations

Levetiracetam

Skeletal abnormalities

Lamotrigine

Cleft lip/palate

Topiramate

Cleft lip/palate

Carbamazepine/oxcarbazepine

Fetal hydantoin syndrome

questions.text: A pregnant woman in her second trimester presents to the emergency department following a severe motor vehicle accident. She is stable but requires an urgent CT imaging of her pelvis to rule out internal injuries. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the pelvic area. The estimated fetal radiation exposure from a pelvic CT scan is 1 rad. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Perform a fetal MRI to assess for any structural abnormalities.

options.label: C
options.text: Reassure the patient that the fetal dose is within acceptable limits and continue prenatal care.

options.label: D
options.text: Proceed with the pelvic CT scan.

questions.correct_answer: D. Proceed with the pelvic CT scan.
questions.explanation:
Gestational Age (weeks)

<5 rad

5–10 rad

>10 rad

0-2

None

None

None

3-4

None

Probably None

Low risk of spontaneous abortion

5-10

None

Not clinically detectable

Possible malformations

11-17

None

Not clinically detectable

Risk of decreased IQ or of mental retardation

18-27

None

None

IQ deficits not detectable at diagnostic

doses

>27

None

None

None

questions.text: During a routine prenatal examination at 36 weeks gestation, a pregnant woman complains of occasional abdominal discomfort and pressure. On palpation, the obstetrician notes the fetal head is engaged in the pelvis. Which obstetric maneuver would be most appropriate to confirm the position of the fetal head?
questions.explanation:
Leopold's Maneuver

Position

Technique

Purpose

Fundal Grip (First Leopold)

Facing the patient’s face

Palpate the fundal area with both hands

Determine which fetal pole is in the fundus

  • Broad, soft, irregular mass: Breech
  • Smooth, hard, globular mass: Head
  • Transverse lie: Neither pole palpable

Lateral or Umbilical Grip (Second Leopold)

Facing the patient’s face

Place hands flat on either side of the umbilicus, palpate one side at a time

Identify the position of the fetal back, limbs, and anterior shoulder

  • Back: Smooth, curved, resistant
  • Limb side: Comparatively empty with small, knob-like parts
  • Anterior shoulder: Prominent in the lower part of the uterus above the head

Pawlik’s Grip (Third Leopold)

Facing the patient’s face

Place thumb and four fingers over the lower pole of the uterus, ulnar border on the upper symphysis pubis

Grasp the presenting part if not engaged and test its mobility

  • Transverse lie: Pawlik’s grip is empty

Pelvic Grip (Fourth Leopold)

Facing the patient’s feet

Place four fingers of both hands on either side of the midline in the lower pole of the uterus, pressing downward and backward
  • Identify the part in the lower pole, its attitude, and engagement
  • Head Characteristics:
    • Precise presenting area
    • Attitude (position of sinciput and occiput)
    • Engagement (noted by the presence/absence of sinciput and occiput, convergence/divergence of finger tips)

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 33 weeks gestation presents for a routine prenatal visit. She reports decreased fetal movements over the past two days. She has a history of gestational diabetes, and her pregnancy has been otherwise uneventful. The doctor decides to perform antepartum fetal surveillance. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial test to assess the fetal well-being in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Fetal movement

Maternal observation and recording of fetal movements to assess fetal well-being and activity levels.

Non-stress test (NST)

Monitors fetal heart rate acceleration in response to fetal movements to assess fetal well-being.

Biophysical profile (BPP)

(Option B ruled out)

Assesses fetal well-being based on fetal heart rate accelerations, fetal movements, muscle tone, breathing movements, and amniotic fluid volume

Doppler velocimetry

Uses ultrasound to assess blood flow in fetal vessels like umbilical artery, middle cerebral artery (MCA), and ductus venosus, aiding in the evaluation of fetal well-being and placental function

Amniotic fluid index (AFI)

(Option A ruled out)

Measures the depth of amniotic fluid to assess fetal well-being and detect potential complications like oligohydramnios or polyhydramnios

Contraction stress test (CST)

(Option C ruled out)

Evaluates fetal heart rate response to uterine contractions to assess fetal well-being and uteroplacental function under controlled stress conditions.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 24 weeks gestation comes to the clinic for a routine prenatal visit. She has no significant medical history and reports feeling well, with normal fetal movements. Which method would be most appropriate for monitoring fetal heart sounds at this stage of her pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Hand held doppler

Detect and amplify fetal heart sounds, typically starting around 10-12 weeks of gestation

Fetoscope

A specialized stethoscope designed for listening directly to fetal heart sounds through the maternal abdomen, usually used after 18-20 weeks of gestation.

Electronic Fetal Monitoring (EFM)

Continuous or intermittent electronic monitoring of fetal heart rate and uterine contractions during labor using external or internal sensors

Fetal Phonocardiography

A method that records and analyzes fetal heart sounds to assess cardiac function and detect abnormalities, sometimes used in research or specialized clinical settings.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines can a pregnant woman receive?
questions.explanation:
Vaccines contraindicated in pregnancy

(Option A, C and D)
  • Measles
  • Mumps
  • Rubella
  • Varicella
  • Smallpox
  • Zoster

Used in high risk of contracting infection
  • Polio
  • Yellow fever
  • Influenza (Option B)
  • Rabies
  • Hepatitis B
  • Hepatitis A
  • Pneumococcus
  • Meningococcus
  • Typhoid
  • Anthrax

Not recommended
  • HPV

Recommeneded
  • Tetanus-diphtheria-acelluar pertussis

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman at 16 weeks of gestation presents to her obstetrician. The quad test had shown an elevated risk for Down’s syndrome. How to make a definitive diagnosis of Down’s syndrome in the fetus?
questions.explanation:
First trimester

Second trimester

Timing

11 - 14 weeks

15 - 22 weeks

Screening test

(Option A and B ruled out )
  • PAPP-A (Pregnancy Associated Plasma Protein-A)
  • Free beta-hCG
  • Ultrasound measurement of Nuchal translucency (NT) and nasal bone
  • Quad test:
    • Maternal Serum Alpha Fetoprotein (MSAFP)
    • Unconjugated estriol (uE3)
    • Dimeric inhibin-A
    • hCG
 
  • If NT is ≥ 3 mm in the first trimester - ultrasound and fetal echocardiography

 

Chorionic Villus Sampling

Amniocentesis

Cordocentesis

Timing
  • Transcervical:10–13 weeks
  • Transabdominal:10 weeks to term

After 15 weeks

(Option C)

18–20 weeks

(Option D ruled out)

Materials for study

Trophoblast cells

Fetal fibroblasts

Fetal white blood cells

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with active labor. She is gravida 2, para 1, with a previous history of a cesarean section. She has a singleton pregnancy at 39 weeks gestation, and her current pregnancy has been uncomplicated. On examination, she is in spontaneous labor with a cephalic presentation. According to Robson’s classification, which group does she belong to?
questions.explanation:
Group

Description

1

Nullipara, single, cephalic, term pregnancy, spontaneous labour

2 (Option A ruled out)

Nullipara, single, cephalic, term, induced labour or planned Cesarean section (CS)

3 (Option B ruled out)

Multipara without uterine scar, single, cephalic, term, spontaneous labour

4 (Option C ruled out)

Multipara without uterine scar, single, cephalic, term, induced labour or planned CS

5 (Option D)

Multipara with uterine scar, single, cephalic, term

6

Nullipara, single, Breech presentation

7

Multipara, single, breech, including previous CS

8

Multiple Pregnancy

9

Single, abnormal lie, including previous scar

10

Single, Cephalic, Preterm including previous scar

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman who is currently 19 weeks pregnant. She missed her first-trimester screening and is now anxious about the possibility of her baby having a chromosomal abnormality, given her advanced maternal age. She comes for her second-trimester screening appointment. A quadruple marker test was ordered and it returned with a positive result for suspected Down’s syndrome. Which of the following results corresponds to Down’s syndrome?
questions.correct_answer: C. ↓ AFP, ↑ hCG, ↓ uE3, ↑ Inhibin A
questions.explanation:
Quadruple Marker

Down’s Syndrome (Option C)

Edward’s Syndrome

(Option A ruled out)

Patau’s Syndrome

(Option B ruled out)

Alpha Feto-Protein (AFP)

↓

↓

↓

Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG)

↑

↓

↓

Unconjugated Estriol (uE3)

↓

↓

↓

Inhibin A

↑

-

↓

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents for her routine prenatal check-up. She is currently 11 weeks pregnant and feeling anxious about her pregnancy due to her age and the risk of chromosomal abnormalities associated with it. During a fetal aneuploidy screening, risk of Trisomy 21 is increased. What would be the levels of Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) and Pregnancy-associated Plasma Protein-A (PAPP-A) in Trisomy 21?
questions.correct_answer: A. Increased hCG and Decreased PAPP-A.

questions.text: What are the minimum number of antenatal care (ANC) visits according to WHO and Government of India respectively?
questions.explanation:
WHO Recommended Minimum ANC visits: 8

Govt. Of India Recommended Minimum ANC Visits: 4

Ideal number of visits: 13 or 14

1st Trimester - 1 visit. (within 12 weeks of gestation)

1st visit- <12 weeks

Upto 7 months: once every month

2nd Trimester - 2 visits. (weeks - 20 & 26)

2nd visit- 14-26 weeks

8th month: twice every month

3rd Trimester - 5 visits. (weeks - 30, 34, 36, 38 & 40)

3rd visit- 28-32 weeks

9th month: Once every week
 

4th visit- 36 weeks to term

questions.text: Which of the following statements are incorrect regarding transvaginal ultrasound (TVS)?

options.label: A
options.text: Fetal pole and cardiac activity can be determined within 5-6 weeks using TVS

options.label: B
options.text: The double decidual sign is a potential indicator for early intra-uterine pregnancy

options.label: C
options.text: Gestational sac is the first sonographic evidence of pregnancy and is seen in the middle of the endometrial cavity.

options.label: D
options.text: Gestational sac may be seen as early as Upto 4-5 weeks of gestation with TVS

questions.correct_answer: C. Gestational sac is the first sonographic evidence of pregnancy and is seen in the middle of the endometrial cavity.
questions.explanation:
Structure

Timing

Gestational sac (1st sonographic evidence of pregnancy) (Option D ruled out)

4-5 weeks

Yolk sac

5.5 weeks

Fetal pole and cardiac activity (Option A ruled out)

5-6 weeks

questions.text: A lady who is 24 weeks pregnant came to the OPD for routine antenatal check up. She has a history of normal twin delivery 3 years back and 2 abortions. What is is her obstetric score?
questions.explanation:
Gravida

Denotes a pregnant state, both present and past, irrespective ofthe  period of gestation

Parity

Denotes a state of previous pregnancy beyond the period of viability(28 weeks)

Abortion

Number of pregnancies lost before 24 weeks

Living

Living children

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents for her first prenatal visit. Her last menstrual period (LMP) was recorded as February 15, 2024. She reports regular 28-day menstrual cycles. What is her estimated delivery date (EDD)?
